title: Theresa May visited a school and appeared horrified at the concept of Lego robots

organizations.name: facebook follow us on twitter politics newsletter follow

text:
Theresa May visited a school and appeared horrified at the concept of Lego robots Was the Prime Minister finally facing up to the reality that one day these schoolchildren will build a robot that will replace her? Share Comments By Mikey Smith 17:29, 15 FEB 2017 News Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch Next WATCH IN FULL: Prime Minister's Question Time Jer Watch this video again Watch Next Theresa May keeps Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu w 1:00 Theresa May mistakes EU advisor for government ai 0:27 Speaker John Bercow handed blunt slapdown on his 2:26 Shocking video shows prisoners "high on the synth 3:22 National Lottery results: Lotto and Thunderball n 2:03 Dramatic moment two Brits are plucked to safety a 1:12 Fear spreads across Paris as riots in suburbs spi 0:56 Donald Trump brags about Electoral College votes 2:03 Prankster dressed as Domino's worker buys pizzas 0:59 President Trump says Mike Flynn was treated unfai 0:55 Kylie Jenner and Tyga visit the Empire State buil 0:31 Video will play in Theresa May visits a school in Copeland ahead of by-election Share this video Watch Next Share Comments Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email Theresa May appeared horrified by the concept of schoolchildren building robots out of Lego during a visit to Copeland today.
The Prime Minister recoiled in revulsion as primary school pupils demonstrated their ability to fashion rudimentary automatons out of the toy building blocks.
She was visiting the school ahead of a crucial by-election in the region, to take place next week.
During the visit, the PM refused to say whether she opposed plans to scrap or downgrade the maternity ward in a local hospital.
But it's possible she was simply preoccupied by the tiny wheeled mechanoids.
What could possibly have been running through her mind?
Oh, this seems harmless enough (Photo: Getty Images Europe) But hang on a minute... (Photo: PA) How many of these things have you made? (Photo: PA) The unemployment figures are bad enough without introducing robots to the workforce (Photo: Getty Images Europe) And if small children can build them, what's stopping corporations building them? (Photo: PA) Oh, that kind of thing never ends well... (Photo: BBC) (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) My God...what if they build one that can replace ME?
